rows.text: How he was as difficult to tackle as a freight train; "A" is a reference to his surname initial
His remarkable ability to maintain a high level of play during the latter years of his 20 year career.
AD/All Day or AD or AP or Purple Jesus
Given to him by his parents because he would run "all day", his initials
Given to him by Buffalo Bills fans because of his scraggly beard during the 2010 NFL season.
His ability to return kicks and punts for touchdowns any time. Inspired from his mentor Deion "Prime Time" Sanders.
For his speed, and his spectacular and graceful moves.
He used this term to describe himself during an interview. Afterward fans continued to use the term.
Apparent reference to his large size and penchant for eating
His blond hair combined with his tendencies to throw the ball down the field, hence "bomber"
Reference to the wide avenue that ran through New York—the city where he played QB with the New York Jets
Play on Brees's last name and his perception as the savior of Saints Football.
Play on Cushing's last name and his hard-hitting tackles.
Given both because of his ability to break long runs and because it rhymes with his last name. Got the name in college.
Because of his ability to carry tacklers on his back like a "bus"
CJ for Chris Johnson, 2K for his 2000-yard rushing season, 2 as a play on CJ2K and a reference to his poor performance towards the beginning of the 2011 season
Because of missing only 3 games in his 13 season of playing, as well as his offseason employment as a concrete salesman.
Was plagued by concussions and injuries, referencing his presumed fragility
Because of his powerback style of play—compared to a truck that ran on diesel.
Because of his physical tackling, and apparent resemblance to the cartoon character
Carolina Panthers running back duo from 2008–present, previously known as Smash and Dash
His initials. Also went by D.D.T. (bestowed by fans) which stood for "Dangerous Derrick Thomas" and after the toxic synthetic pesticide
Allusion to an incident which allegedly occurred when he was in college as well as a take on one-time teammate Jerome Bettis' nickname, "The Bus"
His all-around skills at Running Back
His ability to turn around a long-struggling Buffalo Bills offensive attack after several years of mediocrity. It was later turned around to Fitztragic when his play, as well as the team's, declined.
His stunning plays combined with his number, 80
His style of diving into receivers and diving into pass paths for interception, and for Polamalu's Polynesian ancestry (Polamalu is in fact Samoan, but Hawaiian rhymes better)
Combine stats off the charts for someone his size
Because no one could catch him
Earned nickname in honor of his celebratory dance following a thunderous tackle.
Reference to his ability to kick long Field Goals and also because "Leg" rhymes with his first name.
Shortening of his last name which is Gronkowski.

He earned this nickname for his intrepid attitude on the field, his legendary toughness and ability to come back from and play through injuries, and the fact that he threw bullet passes so hard he was known to break his receiver's fingers. The "gunslinger mentality" refers to Favre's tendency to fearlessly force throws to covered receivers, a high risk/high reward style of play.

Earned his nickname in 1969 by cutting an abandoned 1953 Chevrolet Bel Air in half with a hacksaw after his previously unbeaten University of Tennessee team returned from an embarrassing 38–0 road loss to Ole Miss.
Earned his nickname because of impact of hits he put on opposing ball carriers and QBs. Played his entire career with the Atlanta Falcons and was part of the 1998 "Dirty Birds" team.
His size and left-handed throwing motion
Play on the first syllable of his name.
Nickname given to him by coach Vermeil because of his big play ability in the return game
Given by Rich Eisen: The Inconvenient truth was the name of former Vice President Al Gore's book/film
His hard-nosed straight-ahead, bruising running style.
Used by multiple media outlets for his ability to tip passes at the line of scrimmage. Began towards the start of the 2012 NFL season.
Jake "daylight come and you gotta" Delhomme
His ability to remain calm in pressure situations
His initials (which also are used to refer to orange juice)
Given for his big, hard hits
"Kansas Comet" was stuck on him by the Director of Sports Information at the University of Kansas.
Play on the length of his full name and its resemblance to the name of a law firm
Because of his reputation of being a hard hitter; has been shortened to "Lights" by teammates in interviews
An alternate take on his initials, and a reference to his ability to run away from competitors
Because of his short legs, he appeared to waddle like a duck.
Because of his physical running style and reputation for repeatedly breaking tackles
In reference to Natural Ice or "Natty Ice", an adult beverage loved by bros across America.
The Savior for the Vikings. In his rookie year, Moss led the Vikings towards one of the most powerful offenses in the NFL.
His flashy play and the rhyme with his first name
To his homeland as well as to the difficulty he posed to defenses
Due to his fear of flying, Lane road a night train to away games while the rest of the team flew

Self-bestowed pidgin Spanish reference to his uniform number (85); originally named Chad Johnson, legally changed name to "Chad Ochocinco" in 2008 (changed back to Johnson in 2012). Also self-refers as "Esteban Ochocinco".
For his ability to defeat tight coverage, even double coverage, and make big plays.; possibly self-bestowed
For his durability as a featured back, his strength to break tackles and to make crucial pancake blocks (most notably on Shawn Merriman) despite his diminutive size.
Derogatory reference to his repeated season-ending injuries
His ability to step up at critical moments and make big plays; possibly self-bestowed
Reference to the purple uniforms of the Vikings and a takeoff of the 1960s song "One Eyed One Horned Flying Purple People Eater"
Reference to Colston's shyness and ability to make big plays.
His immense size in comparison to other defensive linemen
His ability to cover wide receivers was compared to being stranded on an island
His speed, quickness, agility, and dynamic running ability; given to him while he was at Virginia Tech
His speed; given to him while he was at Notre Dame
His ability to avoid the pass rush; given to him while at Navy
His speed; given to him in beginning of 2011 season, also a play on his initials.
His ability to confuse the opposing offense and make bone crushing tackles.
His ability to avoid defenders in the backfield and penchant for running with the ball if the pass play broke down
Well known for calling his own plays at the line of scrimmage and hurry-up offense.
Playing on both offense and defense (and thus playing all sixty minutes of the game); is sometimes applied generally to any player that does this
The punctuation mark used when describing his dual position as a quarterback/receiver.
His affinity for passing the ball, particularly deep downfield
His effectiveness lining up between the split end/flanker and the linemen (i.e. "the slot")
Earned his nickname from his coach following a long, winding touchdown run
His ability of "snaking" around out of pressure in the pocket; also rhymes with first name

Drafted as a wide receiver by the Minnesota Vikings, on Brett Favre's insistence Joe Webb was signed to the team as a back-up QB. Went on to lead Vikings to a win in Philadelphia, against Michael Vick and the Eagles playing a must-win game. Lovingly called Spiderman, due to his last name.
Due to both his unusually athletic physique and habit of pretending to rip open his jersey to reveal a "S" underneath when scoring a rushing touchdown.
His initials, also referring to the abbreviation for "touchdown"; Davis holds the record for most rushing touchdowns in one Super Bowl game with three
Earned from teammates and other NFL players and Sportscasters, referring to the abbreviation of the Greatest Of All Time.
Used as Tim Tebow for making comebacks in games

Before the Pro Bowl in 2003 Vanderjagt questioned the passion of Colt's teammate Peyton Manning & coach Tony Dungy. In response Manning gave an angry sideline interview in which he acknowledged Vanderjagt as a good kicker, but called him an idiot at least four different times.
Given after Brady's terrific play through much of the 2000s, including 3 Super Bowls, 2 League MVPs, 2 Super Bowl MVPs, and the NFL regular season record for passing touchdowns (50) in 2007.
He plays with a style that borders on reckless, and, like the cartoon character, he is something of whirling dervish.
The duo is largely responsible for the Vikings fielding such a stiff run defense, and they make it nearly impossible for the opposition to consistently gain yardage between the tackles.
Nickname given for Maddox's passing ability, making the Steelers more of a downfield team.
Had a knack for late game come-from-behind wins.
A play on his name, but also his role as a guard when run-blocking.
His hard-hitting, game-changing play style. As well as his flying tackles.
Given by Chris Berman, play on Armani suits.
His choice of footwear at a time when most players wore black cleats
Windy City Flyer and Miami Missile
Hester's speed and a nickname for the city of Chicago, in which he plays; bestowed by WBBM 780 radio-announcer Jeff Joniak
